WIP
> The famous hacker Script K. Iddie has finally been caught after many years of cybercrime. Before he was caught, he released a server sending mysterious data, and promised his 0-days to anyone who could solve his multi-level hacking challenge. Now everyone is in an ARMs race to get his exploits. Can you be the one to solve Iddie's puzzle?
#### Steps
1. First I connected to the instance with netcat
```shell
└─$ nc 94.237.55.163 50810
Level 1/50: 
Register r0:  Timeout! You took too long to provide input.
```
2. It times out after a couple seconds, and inputting a number that is not the right number of bits/ corrent format outputs `wrong answer` or `value not recognized`
3. ARM processors contain 16 32-bit registers, r0-r15
4. Registers r0-r3 pass paramter values into routines and pass result values out. r0 holds the first argument of a function call
5. ARM assembly is hex code derived from binary strings separated into 32 bit chunks
6. Knowing this, I used cyberchef to convert the hex to binary, ensuring the delimeters was a newline (to make parsing easier) and they were in 32 byte chunks before savng it to a text file
```
00000000000000000000000000110111
00000000000000000000000000000011
00000000000000000000000000000001
00000000000000000000000011100011
00000000000000000000000010011100
00000000000000000000000000011011
00000000000000000000000000000111
[ ETC ]
```
7. Since there were a ton of repeating commands, I removed repeat lines with this command
```shell
└─$ sort -u binfile.txt                                   
00000000000000000000000000000000
00000000000000000000000000000001
00000000000000000000000000000010
00000000000000000000000000000011
00000000000000000000000000000100
00000000000000000000000000000101
00000000000000000000000000000110
00000000000000000000000000000111
```

8. I noticed that nothing preceding the last 8 digits of the string changed, so I tried to figure what that section of the instruction controlled
9. I wasn't able to easily find out how the translation was made, so I went back to the instnace for more testing
10. `0000`, `0b0000`, `0x34`, and `0x3478` gave `wrong answer` but `0001` gave `value not recognized`
11.
